content:
I'm working on updating the contributor survey to include some more positively framed questions so we're not only focused on problems as documented in https://github.com/rust-lang/surveys/issues/182 and I'm currently looking for suggestions for options to include with the following question:

"What are the elements of the rust-lang contribution experience that have had the greatest positive impact on your ability to contribute to and/or maintain Rust?"

the question is going to be a multiple choice where each choice has a rating of how relevant it has been, followed by a text field for people to write in any additional experiences that aren't covered by the suggested choices

so yea to reiterate why I opened this stream: Does anyone have suggestions for what choices we should provide by default with this question? Here are the options I've got currently

  • Mentorship, outreach, or encouragement from other project members
  • Learning materials and documentation (rustc-dev-guide, forge, github readmes, API docs)
  • Contribution sprints
  • Welcoming environment with clear path to getting involved
This is a good list. Will people be able to choose more than one? When I answer this question I would want to choose more than one of these answers.

Yes, it will allow for a matrix where you select a rating of how big of an impact each of these has had for you, from zero to large with a follow-up question as a text field for people to fill in anything that's not listed

A few more items, several of which resonate with me:

  • Feeling safe and welcomed within the project
  • Other aspects of project culture (as distinct from the previous point)
  • Rust development processes with low friction
  • Financial support for my work on Rust
  • Community enthusiasm for my work on Rust
  • Personal interest in my work on Rust

Josh Triplett said:

A few more items, several of which resonate with me:

  • Feeling safe and welcomed within the project
  • Other aspects of project culture (as distinct from the previous point)
  • Rust development processes with low friction
  • Financial support for my work on Rust
  • Community enthusiasm for my work on Rust
  • Personal interest in my work on Rust

The last three in this list are excellent additions. The 1st one I think is a restatement of the last item in @Jane Lusby [she/her] 's list. I'm not sure what the 2nd is referring to and likely wouldn't consider it as a respondent. Same for the 3rd. It's meaning is unclear to me. Can you clarify the 2nd and 3rd items in your list @Josh Triplett ?
@Doc Jones To me, the first item is distinct: "safe and welcomed" is not the same thing as "clear path to getting involved"
I'd like to see those two points separated; "clear path to getting involved" is absolutely important, but it seems separate from whether you as a person feel safe and welcome.
There can be a clear path to get involved that's covered in barbed wire and land mines. And you can feel safe and welcome in a project even if it isn't obvious how to start contributing to it.
My third point is probably somewhat close in spirit to "clear path to getting involved", and the two should probably be deduplicated.
My second was meant as one of what might be a couple of catch-all answers; in this case, "other aspects of Rust culture that aren't covered by other answers".

Josh Triplett said:

Doc Jones To me, the first item is distinct: "safe and welcomed" is not the same thing as "clear path to getting involved"

"Welcoming environment" is the phrase I would compare to "safe and welcomed". Maybe merge the two? They would seem redundant if both are included.
I guess my confusion with number 3 is that I don't find Rust development processes low friction. :)
I would separate "safe and welcomed" - IMO it is possible to feel safe without feeling welcome, and welcome without feeling safe

Doc Jones said:

I guess my confusion with number 3 is that I don't find Rust development processes low friction. :) That is: in the absence of mentorship.

That doesn't necessarily indicate that the question would not be helpful, if we get everyone saying that low friction process had zero positive impact on them that's a pretty strong signal that people have a similar experience to you
but it is ambiguous
which is not ideal

Nick Cameron said:

I would separate "safe and welcomed" - IMO it is possible to feel safe without feeling welcome, and welcome without feeling safe

That's fair. I find both feelings important, but that doesn't mean they're inherently connected.
On the subject of splitting questions, you may want to split documentation and learning materials as well as they may have some differences.
fair

Josh Triplett said:

My second was meant as one of what might be a couple of catch-all answers; in this case, "other aspects of Rust culture that aren't covered by other answers".

I don't think this catch-all makes sense as one of the matrix answers, we already have a text field immediately after that is intended to act as a catch-all for anything not listed in the matrix, that way if it's some element of project culture they'll have a chance to call it out more specifically and how it had a positive impact rather than just picking "other culture"
Here's my current version, wdyt?

• Mentorship, outreach, or encouragement from other project members
  • Community Events (Meetups, Conferences, Workshops)
  • Learning materials (rustc-dev-guide, forge, github readmes)
  • Thorough documentation (rustc API docs, std API docs)
  • Contribution sprints
  • Clear path to getting involved
  • Feeling safe within the project
  • Feeling welcomed within the project
  • Financial support for my work on the project
  • Community enthusiasm for my work on the project
  • Personal interest in my work on the project
